description: Service enumeration commands for Linux (systemd/SysV) and Windows privilege escalation

commands.name: List Running systemd Services
commands.description: Show all currently active systemd services (modern Linux distributions)

flag_explanations.list-units: List loaded units (services, sockets, targets, etc.)
flag_explanations.--type=service: Filter to show only service units
flag_explanations.--state=running: Filter to show only services in running state (active)

next_steps: Look for writable service files: find /etc/systemd -writable
Identify services running as root: systemctl status <SERVICE>
commands.notes: systemd is the init system for most modern Linux distributions (RHEL 7+, Ubuntu 16.04+, Debian 8+). OSCP tip: Focus on custom services (not part of base OS) - often have misconfigurations. Time estimate: 2 seconds. To see ALL services (including failed): systemctl list-units --type=service --all

commands.name: List Enabled (Auto-Start) Services
commands.description: Show services configured to start automatically at boot

flag_explanations.list-unit-files: List all available unit files (not just loaded units)
flag_explanations.--state=enabled: Show only services enabled for auto-start at boot

next_steps: Check custom enabled services for persistence mechanisms
Examine service file contents: systemctl cat <SERVICE>
Disable suspicious services: sudo systemctl disable <SERVICE>
commands.notes: Enabled services persist across reboots - key for persistence/backdoor detection. OSCP tip: Custom services in /etc/systemd/system are often exploit targets. Time estimate: 3 seconds.

commands.name: Check systemd Service File Permissions
commands.description: List custom systemd service files with permissions (privilege escalation vector)

flag_explanations.ls -la: Long listing with all files including hidden
flag_explanations.*.service: Wildcard for all service unit files

next_steps: If writable: Modify service to run payload as root
Check ExecStart path in service file: systemctl cat <SERVICE>
Check if service binary is writable: ls -la <EXEC_PATH>
Restart service to trigger payload: sudo systemctl restart <SERVICE>
commands.notes: CRITICAL for OSCP privilege escalation. Writable service files = instant root if service runs as root. Also check /lib/systemd/system/ (system services). Time estimate: 2 seconds. Exploit pattern: (1) Find writable .service file, (2) Modify ExecStart=/path/to/reverse_shell, (3) sudo systemctl restart <SERVICE>.

commands.name: SysV Init Services Status
commands.description: List all SysV init services with status (+ running, - stopped) - older Linux systems

flag_explanations.--status-all: Display status of all services (+ for running, - for stopped, ? for unknown)

next_steps: Look for writable init scripts for privilege escalation
commands.notes: SysV init used on older Linux (pre-systemd). Still found in OSCP labs. [+] = running, [-] = stopped, [?] = status unknown. Time estimate: 3 seconds. Service scripts in /etc/init.d/ - check permissions for privesc.

commands.name: SysV Runlevel Configuration
commands.description: Show which SysV services are enabled at each runlevel (RHEL/CentOS)

flag_explanations.--list: List all services and their runlevel configuration (0-6 runlevels)

next_steps: Disable malicious service: sudo chkconfig <SERVICE> off
Check service script permissions for privesc
commands.notes: RHEL/CentOS specific. Runlevels: 0=halt, 1=single-user, 3=multi-user, 5=graphical, 6=reboot. Time estimate: 2 seconds.

commands.name: Windows List All Services
commands.description: List all Windows services with current state using Service Control command

flag_explanations.query: Query service status (no arguments = all services)

next_steps: Look for unquoted service paths: win-wmic-service-path
commands.notes: Service Control (sc.exe) is built-in Windows service management tool. OSCP tip: Focus on services with STATE=RUNNING and user-created services (non-Microsoft). Time estimate: 5 seconds.

commands.name: Windows List All Services (Including Stopped)
commands.description: Query all services including stopped ones (comprehensive service enumeration)

flag_explanations.state= all: Include all states (running, stopped, paused). NOTE: Space after '=' is required by sc.exe syntax

next_steps: Look for services with weak permissions
commands.notes: Space after '=' is REQUIRED: 'state= all' not 'state=all'. Shows stopped services which may have weak permissions or unquoted paths. Time estimate: 10 seconds.

commands.name: Windows Service Configuration Details
commands.description: Get detailed configuration for specific Windows service (binary path, start type, dependencies)

flag_explanations.qc: Query Configuration - shows service configuration details including BINARY_PATH_NAME, START_TYPE, DEPENDENCIES

failure_indicators: The specified service does not exist
next_steps: Check if BINARY_PATH_NAME has unquoted spaces: win-unquoted-service-path-check
Check if SERVICE_START_NAME is LocalSystem (high privileges)
Modify service binary if writable: win-sc-config-binpath
commands.notes: CRITICAL for Windows privilege escalation. Check for: (1) Unquoted service paths with spaces, (2) Writable service binaries, (3) Services running as LocalSystem/SYSTEM. Time estimate: 1 second. Common privesc: Unquoted path 'C:\Program Files\My Service\service.exe' â†’ Place malicious 'C:\Program.exe'.

commands.name: WMIC Service Enumeration
commands.description: List all Windows services with brief details using WMI

flag_explanations.brief: Display brief format (ExitCode, Name, ProcessId, StartMode, State, Status)

next_steps: Filter running services: wmic service where "State='Running'" list brief
Check for non-standard services (not from Microsoft)
commands.notes: WMIC deprecated in Windows 11+ but still in OSCP labs. For specific properties: wmic service get Name,PathName,StartMode,State. Time estimate: 5 seconds.

commands.name: WMIC Service Paths (Unquoted Path Check)
commands.description: List Windows services with full binary paths to identify unquoted service path vulnerabilities

flag_explanations.Name: Service name
flag_explanations.PathName: Full path to service executable (CRITICAL for finding unquoted paths)

next_steps: Identify unquoted paths with spaces: PathName without quotes and containing spaces
Place malicious executable in exploitable path
Restart service: sc stop <SERVICE> && sc start <SERVICE>
commands.notes: CRITICAL Windows privesc technique. Unquoted path 'C:\Program Files\My App\service.exe' allows placing 'C:\Program.exe' or 'C:\Program Files\My.exe'. Time estimate: 5 seconds. Filter for unquoted: wmic service get Name,PathName | findstr /v /i "C:\Windows" | findstr /i /v '"'.

commands.name: PowerShell Get Services
commands.description: PowerShell cmdlet to list running Windows services

flag_explanations.$_.Status -eq \"Running\": Filter to show only services with Running status

next_steps: Check service binary paths: Get-WmiObject win32_service
commands.notes: Modern PowerShell approach. For all services: Get-Service (no filter). For stopped: Where-Object {$_.Status -eq 'Stopped'}. Time estimate: 3 seconds.

commands.name: PowerShell Service Details with Paths
commands.description: PowerShell WMI query for service details including executable paths

flag_explanations.PathName: Full path to service executable (unquoted path detection)

commands.notes: PowerShell WMI approach (modern). Time estimate: 5 seconds. One-liner for unquoted path detection: Get-WmiObject win32_service | Where-Object {$_.PathName -notlike '"*' -and $_.PathName -like '* *' -and $_.PathName -like 'C:\Program*'} | Select Name,PathName
